Description: Mould-made disc-shaped scaraboid in glazed composition; slightly domed and plain back with straight sides; underside decorated with representation of falcon, with two debased hieroglyphic signs including a sun-disc (more oval than round) and an attempt to represent a hes-vase (?) but showed horizontally; motif rather carved out than stamped, and, encircled by groove barely visible near edge (almost completely abraded); pierced through diameter; unglazed or glaze completely lost; in pale yellowish paste; eroded.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The hieroglyphic inscription on its underside does not seem to make sense. The hieroglyphs are probably used here for their magical value as often for this type of scarab (Gorton 1996, 93). Falcon is a common theme on scarabs and scaraboids produced at the “Scarab Factory” and appears on various compositions (on productions of the Scarab Factory, see Webb forthcoming). This scaraboid is close to a type that was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 93, 99, 106-107, type XXVIII A, subtype 149-158, see especially no. 152 for this piece). The motif on the underside, however, seems to be carved out rather than stamped, so it does not share the technical characteristics as defined in Gorton's type XXVIII. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum, 16th –17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 54)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 99, Type XXVIII A152)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OD.023) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4909 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
